t: Luke 7
The Faith of the Centurion
When*p Jesus had finished saying all this to the people who were listening, he entered Capernaum.
There a centurion’s servant, whom his master valued highly, was sick and about to die.
The centurion heard of Jesus and sent some elders of the Jews to him, asking him to come and heal his servant.
When they came to Jesus, they pleaded earnestly with him, “This man deserves to have you do this,
because he loves our nation and has built our synagogue.”
So Jesus went with them. He*p was not far from the house when the centurion sent friends to say to him: “Lord, don’t trouble yourself, for I do not deserve to have you come under my roof.
That is why I did not even consider myself worthy to come to you. But say the word, and my servant will be healed.
For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”
When*p Jesus heard this, he was amazed at him, and turning to the crowd following him, he said, “I*r tell*r you,*r I*r have*r not*r found*r such*r great*r faith*r even*r in*r Israel.”*r
Then the men who had been sent returned to the house and found the servant well.
Jesus Raises a Widow’s Son
Soon*p afterward, Jesus went to a town called Nain, and his disciples and a large crowd went along with him.
As he approached the town gate, a dead person was being carried out—the only son of his mother, and she was a widow. And a large crowd from the town was with her.
When the Lord saw her, his heart went out to her and he said, “Don’t*r cry.”*r
Then*p he went up and touched the bier they were carrying him on, and the bearers stood still. He said, “Young*r man,*r I*r say*r to*r you,*r get*r up!”*r
The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus gave him back to his mother.
They*p were all filled with awe and praised God. “A great prophet has appeared among us,” they said. “God has come to help his people.”
This news about Jesus spread throughout Judea and the surrounding country.
Jesus and John the Baptist
John’s*p disciples told him about all these things. Calling two of them,
he sent them to the Lord to ask, “Are you the one who is to come, or should we expect someone else?”
When*p the men came to Jesus, they said, “John the Baptist sent us to you to ask, ‘Are you the one who is to come, or should we expect someone else?’ ”
At*p that very time Jesus cured many who had diseases, sicknesses and evil spirits, and gave sight to many who were blind.

So he replied to the messengers, “Go*r back*r and*r report*r to*r John*r what*r you*r have*r seen*r and*r heard:*r The*r blind*r receive*r sight,*r the*r lame*r walk,*r those*r who*r have*r leprosy*r are*r cleansed,*r the*r deaf*r hear,*r the*r dead*r are*r raised,*r and*r the*r good*r news*r is*r proclaimed*r to*r the*r poor.*r
Blessed*r is*r anyone*r who*r does*r not*r stumble*r on*r account*r of*r me.”*r
After*p John’s messengers left, Jesus began to speak to the crowd about John: “What*r did*r you*r go*r out*r into*r the*r wilderness*r to*r see?*r A*r reed*r swayed*r by*r the*r wind?*r
If*r not,*r what*r did*r you*r go*r out*r to*r see?*r A*r man*r dressed*r in*r fine*r clothes?*r No,*r those*r who*r wear*r expensive*r clothes*r and*r indulge*r in*r luxury*r are*r in*r palaces.*r
But*r what*r did*r you*r go*r out*r to*r see?*r A*r prophet?*r Yes,*r I*r tell*r you,*r and*r more*r than*r a*r prophet.*r
This*r is*r the*r one*r about*r whom*r it*r is*r written:*r “ ‘I*rpn will*r send*r my*r messenger*r ahead*r of*r you,*r who*rld will*r prepare*r your*r way*r before*r you.’*r

I*rp tell*r you,*r among*r those*r born*r of*r women*r there*r is*r no*r one*r greater*r than*r John;*r yet*r the*r one*r who*r is*r least*r in*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r is*r greater*r than*r he.”*r
(All*p the people, even the tax collectors, when they heard Jesus’ words, acknowledged that God’s way was right, because they had been baptized by John.
But the Pharisees and the experts in the law rejected God’s purpose for themselves, because they had not been baptized by John.)
Jesus*p went on to say, “To*r what,*r then,*r can*r I*r compare*r the*r people*r of*r this*r generation?*r What*r are*r they*r like?*r

They*r are*r like*r children*r sitting*r in*r the*r marketplace*r and*r calling*r out*r to*r each*r other:*r “ ‘We*rpn played*r the*r pipe*r for*r you,*r and*rld you*r did*r not*r dance;*r we*rln sang*r a*r dirge,*r and*rld you*r did*r not*r cry.’*r
For*rp John*r the*r Baptist*r came*r neither*r eating*r bread*r nor*r drinking*r wine,*r and*r you*r say,*r ‘He*r has*r a*r demon.’*r
The*r Son*r of*r Man*r came*r eating*r and*r drinking,*r and*r you*r say,*r ‘Here*r is*r a*r glutton*r and*r a*r drunkard,*r a*r friend*r of*r tax*r collectors*r and*r sinners.’*r
But*r wisdom*r is*r proved*r right*r by*r all*r her*r children.”*r
Jesus Anointed by a Sinful Woman
When*p one of the Pharisees invited Jesus to have dinner with him, he went to the Pharisee’s house and reclined at the table.
A woman in that town who lived a sinful life learned that Jesus was eating at the Pharisee’s house, so she came there with an alabaster jar of perfume.
As she stood behind him at his feet weeping, she began to wet his feet with her tears. Then she wiped them with her hair, kissed them and poured perfume on them.
When*p the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he said to himself, “If this man were a prophet, he would know who is touching him and what kind of woman she is—that she is a sinner.”
Jesus*p answered him, “Simon,*r I*r have*r something*r to*r tell*r you.”*r “Tell*p me, teacher,” he said.
“Two*rp people*r owed*r money*r to*r a*r certain*r moneylender.*r One*r owed*r him*r five*r hundred*r denarii,*r and*r the*r other*r fifty.*r
Neither*r of*r them*r had*r the*r money*r to*r pay*r him*r back,*r so*r he*r forgave*r the*r debts*r of*r both.*r Now*r which*r of*r them*r will*r love*r him*r more?”*r
Simon*p replied, “I suppose the one who had the bigger debt forgiven.” “You*rp have*r judged*r correctly,”*r Jesus said.

Then*p he turned toward the woman and said to Simon, “Do*r you*r see*r this*r woman?*r I*r came*r into*r your*r house.*r You*r did*r not*r give*r me*r any*r water*r for*r my*r feet,*r but*r she*r wet*r my*r feet*r with*r her*r tears*r and*r wiped*r them*r with*r her*r hair.*r
You*r did*r not*r give*r me*r a*r kiss,*r but*r this*r woman,*r from*r the*r time*r I*r entered,*r has*r not*r stopped*r kissing*r my*r feet.*r
You*r did*r not*r put*r oil*r on*r my*r head,*r but*r she*r has*r poured*r perfume*r on*r my*r feet.*r
Therefore,*r I*r tell*r you,*r her*r many*r sins*r have*r been*r forgiven—as*r her*r great*r love*r has*r shown.*r But*r whoever*r has*r been*r forgiven*r little*r loves*r little.”*r
Then*p Jesus said to her, “Your*r sins*r are*r forgiven.”*r
The*p other guests began to say among themselves, “Who is this who even forgives sins?”
Jesus*p said to the woman, “Your*r faith*r has*r saved*r you;*r go*r in*r peace.”*r
